comments.commentBody: Enough with the nonsense about 'paid mob'.  Considering the millions of people who have protested and the millions who will be protesting, it really shouldn't be too difficult for you to come up with some actually evidence.  After all, if these people are for hire, it should be too hard for you to find someone who was 'hired' and will provide evidence for some more money.  The lack of any evidence to support your wild claims says it all.

Gosh, isn't this just what John C. Calhoun argued about slavery? Just let the states decide the question. Governor Walker has raped social programs in Wisconsin and now he blames the federal government for all the ills that the American people face! " I personally made the case for returning authority to the states..."Walker opines about the Govs. meeting in D.C.

Ahem, let's just for a moment look at the "new poll tax and literacy tests" Southern states imposed after the Supreme Court caved on voting rights. Yeah, just let the states do all they can to disenfranchise voters who are poor, of color etc.

These are debased, and dangerous trends supported by the GOP.
They have been debunked by facts. All hail the GOP! The grand Ostrich Party with their heads and other body parts in the sand.

What Christopher Steele knows about Trump and the Russians and Trump's tax returns are secret and have to be made public. The survival of our democracy may depend on it. It is time for all Republican patriots to show their true colors and do everything they can to expose the rot in the Trump campaign and administration.

I would think China sees a nuclear North Korea in its best interest to prevent a bellicose U.S. constantly probing China's military strength/weakness, naval ships prowling the waters near China, Trump blabbing about trade retaliation  and constant talk by our government officials, including Obama, that China is our biggest threat down the road.  If you were China, what would you do?
I do not understand the lying about the contacts. Evidence shows that the contacts were routine contacts in which  government officials often participate.
Russians have amazingly poor diets. All that vodka and fatty foods. No wonder people die of "heart attacks" all the time. /sarc.
I wonder when the first of, surely, a series of movies is due on Trump and his sorry band of tossers. It can't be far off, can it? Imagine that at the Oscars.

Gail, I select option C). Attorney General Sessions needs to be fired (but give him 24 hours to voluntarily resign, since he does have that elfin smile) and a special prosecutor needs to be named to investigate the administration's relationship with the Russians prior to the election.

One does not question that certain key members of the administration need to regularly interact with Russian officials, such as Ambassador Sergey Kislyak, however, I would argue that those officials should be members of the State and Defense Departments. The president's son-in-law, nor any others on his campaign staff, should not have been interacting with Kislyak nor any other Russian officials prior to the election. The fact that they apparently did is not only unprecedented, but highly questionable. These meetings need to be explained and so far the administration has not offered an adequate explanation.

As for Session's meetings with Kislyak, if they were perfectly innocent, why were they held in conjunction with the Republican National Convention? And why did he lie about them during his confirmation hearings? This is not, contrary to #45's early morning tweets, the same as Sen. Schumer sharing coffee and donuts with Vladimir Putin at a public event.

The administration and the Republicans in Congress will do well to remember that it wasn't a bungled burglary at the DNC that ultimately brought down Nixon, it was the coverup.
Misspoke? Sessions lied!

It isn't just the money that terrifies me as the possible motivation for Trump administration ties. It is also the ideological connection. The fact that Putin is funding right - wing organizations across Europe. If Trump/Bannon want to further their xenophobic campaign, Putin is a great ally.

@Rita
According to Wikipedia, North Korea has about 1.3 million active soldiers plus 4.7 million reservists. The total population is about 24 million.
Atomic bombs are not defensive weapons, because after detonating one of them you start from scrap. Look up pictures of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, before and after. And, by the way, the Koreas still are in state of war. There is just a ceasefire - since 1953. You also should take into account that after Korea there was another war: Vietnam. With a bad outcome!

Does anyone know what the North Korea leader wants? Yes he wants nuclear weapons and ICBMs. Yes he wants power. What else does he want? Peace? War? Or does he want us to feed his people for free? If thats what he wants, lets feed his people. Make them stronger and one day they will overthrow him. The current strategy will have one end. Japan the first and only country ever to have suffered from a nuclear bomb  will become the only country in history to suffer thrice.

I’ve never understood. Why do we get to have nuclear weapons, but people we don’t like aren’t supposed to have them? Yes, I know that from at least the time of Thucydides and the Melian Dialogue, might makes right, according to those with the might. And I’m sure I’d be censured if I found any sort of moral equivalence between our fearless leader and North Korea’s. But in the end, nothing I read about how terrible it would be for Iran or N. Korea to have nukes ever seems to mention how terrible it is that so many other countries have them. What am I missing?

As a Californian, take it from me I'd rather have a check on North Korean missiles heading to the state then the silly wall. Immigrants crossing our southern border pose no where near the threat these missiles do.

" I'd rather have a check on North Korean missiles heading to the state then the silly wall"

That is like saying, "I would rater have food than shelter". We need both and the projected cost of the wall is under $25 billion, or far less than .1% of the US budget.

As a Californian, you do not WANT the wall. But don't pretend that the wall prevents us from protecting ourselves from North Korea. It would in fact remove one contentious issue - further illegal immigration. Then it would leave us free to ask, "What shall we do with people who are already here?" And "What shall we do about North Korea?"

There was a typo.  The cost of the wall is less than 1% of the US federal budget.  Still, a small amount in the greater scheme of things, and a one time expense versus the yearly costs of defense or Medicaid.
Really? I thought his most pressing concern is getting a piece of that 500 billion Russian oil deal with Exxon.

On the contrary, I believe everyone on the planet should know, if they haven't already conjured up the potential situation in their own mind to begin with.

The first time I saw Kim parading missiles like the USSR used to do on May Day I was made aware of the fact it was never a question of if, but when.
I imagine the Chinese realize his missiles could also hit them.  Considering the hostility between the two leaders, once he has his systems up and running, he will probably point some at them as well
The murder of Un's half brother and execution of his uncle demonstrates that any friendship with China is no guarantee of peace in East Asia.

Nothing that Trump inherited matters. The fact that he even considered attacking North Korea should jolt people out of their stupor regarding him. He spins his own truth, out of the spontaneous combustion of his random thoughts, reacts without consideration or information. This appeals to the voters who need him to vent their hatred of a democracy based on human kindness, who more want to their fears and frustrations. His arrogant self-confidence misleads many pundits, many media outlets, who continue to normalize him, as if he is a rational being. He is not.

You are right but the problem started with Bill Clinton when we gave them food aid but had no inspections on the agreement to stop enrichment. Can't blame just one party either, both have allowed this boil to fester and it will lead to disaster if not stopped. The Chinese can solve this problem but the USA refuses to play hard ball with them.

The US is faced with having to choose between the lesser of evils. The strategy we've used for the past two decades to rein in North Korea's nuclear ambitions obviously hasn't worked. If we stay this course, then we are guaranteeing that in a short while North Korea will have an ICBM-based nuclear arsenal in the hands of a ruthless and unstable leader. That cannot be allowed to happen.

The remaining alternative involves military action which should always be the last option. While military action has the risk of unintended consequences, the issue is whether that risk is outweighed by the alternative of no action.

It is time for the US and its allies to destroy the North Korean nuclear and missile capability and to take out their murderous ruling regime. I understand the turmoil this would create, including a huge humanitarian crisis and large financial burden, and I also understand there is no guarantee of total success. In my opinion, however, there is no other less-risky alternative at this point.
Sadly, I have to agree.  And those of us living on Pacific Islands are watching the advancements in the NK offensive nuclear program with increasing concern...

First, neither the NY Times nor any news outlet, should be publishing any kind of information that could benefit regimes such as North Korea, especially details on counter measures, however limited.

Perhaps it's to unsettle the lunatic dear leader, and if such be the case, I urge caution as he may decide to quickly use, or lose, whatever nuclear weaponry he has.

How can we be so incredibly stupid to allow this regime to become such a threat to its neighbors and the world.
Maybe this is the only way for employees to get information to their boss.

It's so serious that Trump reviews intel on the patio at Mar a Lago with his cronies? No, Trump is our greatest problem enabled by Republicans who want tax cuts for the rich, dismantling of federal departments, privatizing social security and repealing ACA. Once they shove their agenda down our throats, Trump will have served their (and your) purpose and dump him.

It is stunning to consider how deeply Hillary Clinton understands this loaded issue in comparison with the man who now sits in the Oval Office. Yet, to many kind and earnest people during the election, nothing was more important than the GOP's promise to "protect the unborn." I still find this myopic perspective astonishing. It was bizarre to watch even a kind, dear friend who has always prided herself on her Evy League education embraced this reasoning -- in her earnest effort to be a good Christian. Now the enormous risks involved in single-issue voting are taking effect. Tomorrow morning, I will go to church as usual, smile warmly at my Republican neighbors who worked hard to put Trump into the White House, while shivering inside at the danger of such a myopic perspective. I remind myself that we each tried to do what we thought was right in the election booth. And I wonder: if only an international education were required to graduate from high school. Other countries require their students to spend thousands of hours studying English by the time they are old enough to vote. If only we used that time to require students to developed a nuanced understanding of the world -- including Asia.
Please excuse my many typographical errors.

Your friend should have read the Constitution and the founders letters during her Ivy League education.

A Christian is a follower of Christ. Christ said nothing about abortion, ever. Period.

The GOP can't even protect the born.

Seems to me his most pressing concern is spell-checking tweets and raving about his massive, never before in history electoral college 'win'. Dumb Donnie can't focus on anything besides the last thing he heard about on cable channels, never mind foreign threats. He undermines himself. Even the Dems aren't creative enough to make up the spectacular fails coming out of the Trump white house.

Has anyone discussed a diplomatic solution involving the reunification of North and South Korea? I'd like to see this as part of a plan to eliminate their fears of being invaded and their associated need for a nuclear defense. Past strategies aren't getting us anywhere closer to solving this problem.

Sounds like a great plan, Steve. One teeny-tiny little snag could be convincing the North Korean government to surrender its power. However, their past behavior has shown them to be a sane and responsible group of folks, so I am sure they will give up with no questions asked.

Or maybe, instead of cutting non-military budgets to the bone, some cultural and student exchange programs?  So there might be some understanding among some North Koreans that our sole reason for being isn't to destroy them?

We and the South Koreans can handle it. It worked for West and East Germany. Let's put our State Department to work. It would be lots cheaper than a military solution. But I see my thoughts only got 2 recommends. Sigh.
